-->; <br />; <h2>;ARCore and the Scene Semantic API</h2>; <p>; Among the new features of <a href="https://developers.google.com/ar">;ARCore</a>; announced by the AR team at I/O, the <a href="https://developers.google.com/ar/develop/scene-semantics">;Scene Semantic API</a>; can recognize pixel-wise semantics in an outdoor scene. This helps users create custom AR experiences based on the features in the surrounding area. This API is empowered by the outdoor semantic segmentation model, leveraging our recent works around the <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.02611">;DeepLab</a>; architecture and an egocentric outdoor scene understanding dataset. The latest ARCore release also includes an improved monocular depth model that provides higher accuracy in outdoor scenes. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjGnl1lYcfkaoqmwIOqb1R8bojq_bbIgiGYC9cMuTGO5hqwsrdXHhGaHIBlfAPwTob-KpyVXUFt-8_NPu1GPhZgmbyfT-ILRDmn980P_tkb0jfwzNNw0cannsvSNTiMyRcntVJ9AyjfnGT5Q4ZBBotOx4MJPOOCF57Ejs0VN1evKjubZQYpyX_NfMtx4A/s486/image3.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="486" data-original-width="242" height="400" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjGnl1lYcfkaoqmwIOqb1R8bojq_bbIgiGYC9cMuTGO5hqwsrdXHhGaHIBlfAPwTob-KpyVXUFt-8_NPu1GPhZgmbyfT-ILRDmn980P_tkb0jfwzNNw0cannsvSNTiMyRcntVJ9AyjfnGT5Q4ZBBotOx4MJPOOCF57Ejs0VN1evKjubZQYpyX_NfMtx4A/w199-h400/image3.gif" width="199" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Scene Semantics API uses DeepLab-based semantic segmentation model to provide accurate pixel-wise labels in a scene outdoors.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <h2>;Chirp</h2>; <p>; <a href="https://cloud.google.com/speech-to-text/v2/docs/chirp-model">;Chirp</a>; is Google's family of state-of-the-art <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/03/universal-speech-model-usm-state-of-art.html">;Universal Speech Models</a>; trained on 12 million hours of speech to enable automatic speech recognition (ASR) for 100+ languages. The models can perform ASR on under-resourced languages, such as Amharic, Cebuano, and Assamese, in addition to widely spoken languages like English and Mandarin. Chirp is able to cover such a wide variety of languages by leveraging <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01037">;self-supervised learning on unlabeled multilingual dataset with fine-tuning on a smaller set of labeled data</a>;. Chirp is now available in the Google Cloud <a href="https://cloud.google.com/speech-to-text">;Speech-to-Text API</a>;, allowing users to perform inference on the model through a simple interface. You can get started with Chirp <a href="https://cloud.google.com/speech-to-text/v2/docs/chirp-model">;here</a>;. </p>; <div style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhtWnj_lXrnnMX5wnXJoWwpRg34v-MyHuSepuvVK4MZfWgbBhGgcMZXPFoSBvS8RIccX9Fes4ASD4mhjrQYyLzZRoaGZjqBrNSfFRChVh1rQ3Disr2q9iO0tiPkHwf3JiReP_0E1nfsS4MWbQwOzxwBHGCX29IhxooTSqw8qhXvQAyoIG9v_SVX6YOHPQ/s591/image7.gif">;<img border="0" data-original-height="250" data-original-width="591" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhtWnj_lXrnnMX5wnXJoWwpRg34v-MyHuSepuvVK4MZfWgbBhGgcMZXPFoSBvS8RIccX9Fes4ASD4mhjrQYyLzZRoaGZjqBrNSfFRChVh1rQ3Disr2q9iO0tiPkHwf3JiReP_0E1nfsS4MWbQwOzxwBHGCX29IhxooTSqw8qhXvQAyoIG9v_SVX6YOHPQ/s16000/image7.gif" />;</a>;</div>; <br />; <h2>;MusicLM</h2>; <p>; At I/O, we launched <a href="https://google-research.github.io/seanet/musiclm/examples/">;MusicLM, a text-to-music model</a>; that generates 20 seconds of music from a text prompt. <a href="https://aitestkitchen.withgoogle.com/experiments/music-lm">;You can try it yourself on AI Test Kitchen</a>;, or see it featured during the I/O preshow, where electronic musician and composer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Deacon">;Dan Deacon</a>; used MusicLM in his performance. </p>; <p>; MusicLM, which consists of models powered by <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/10/audiolm-language-modeling-approach-to.html">;AudioLM</a>; and <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.12415">;MuLAN</a>;, can make music (from text, humming, images or video) and musical accompaniments to singing. AudioLM generates high quality audio with long-term consistency. It maps audio to a sequence of discrete tokens and casts audio generation as a language modeling task. To synthesize longer outputs efficiently, it used a novel approach we've developed called <a href="https://google-research.github.io/seanet/soundstorm/examples/">;SoundStorm</a>;. </p>; <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhiTUOKJuyb19L8ukNhdv51q7M4cMXSJbSnp1n9pd_-vRHzOAW3pENKYWDyBoPKYIN-K9UpduTbXjqQZ3IX5jwtrp0YNu13dZuYC2uIplzl_oSyLDXAhfO6L1kAaXdJXIWWhsGTqJQb-O_0JZ18E4lVNDaT23gMBg9Jcu2r4N_ofkUckaIMSTW0vEJkMQ/s1927/keywordhero.png" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="964" data-original-width="1927" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhiTUOKJuyb19L8ukNhdv51q7M4cMXSJbSnp1n9pd_-vRHzOAW3pENKYWDyBoPKYIN-K9UpduTbXjqQZ3IX5jwtrp0YNu13dZuYC2uIplzl_oSyLDXAhfO6L1kAaXdJXIWWhsGTqJQb-O_0JZ18E4lVNDaT23gMBg9Jcu2r4N_ofkUckaIMSTW0vEJkMQ/s16000/keywordhero.png" />;</a>;</div>; <br />; <h2>;Universal Translator dubbing</h2>; <p>; Our dubbing efforts leverage dozens of ML technologies to translate the full expressive range of video content, making videos accessible to audiences across the world. These technologies have been used to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S-iIV5Oo0n0">;dub videos</a>; across a variety of products and content types, including educational content, advertising campaigns, and creator content, with more to come. We use deep learning technology to achieve <a href="https://developers.googleblog.com/2022/12/improving-video-voice-dubbing-through-deep-learning.html">;voice preservation and lip matching</a>; and enable high-quality video translation. We've built this product to include human review for quality, safety checks to help prevent misuse, and we make it accessible only to authorized partners. </p>; <br />; <h2>;AI for global societal good</h2>; <p>; We are applying our AI technologies to solve some of the biggest global challenges, like mitigating climate change, adapting to a warming planet and improving human health and wellbeing. For example: </p>; <ul>; <li>;Traffic engineers use our Green Light recommendations to reduce stop-and-go traffic at intersections and improve the flow of traffic in cities from Bangalore to Rio de Janeiro and Hamburg. Green Light models each intersection, analyzing traffic patterns to develop recommendations that make traffic lights more efficient — for example, by better synchronizing timing between adjacent lights, or adjusting the “green time” for a given street and direction. </li>;<li>;We've also expanded global coverage on the <a href="https://sites.research.google/floods/l/0/0/3">;Flood Hub</a>; to 80 countries, as part of our efforts to predict riverine floods and alert people who are about to be impacted before disaster strikes. Our <a href="https://sites.research.google/floodforecasting">;flood forecasting efforts</a>; rely on <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2019/09/an-inside-look-at-flood-forecasting.html">;hydrological models</a>; informed by satellite observations, weather forecasts and in-situ measurements. <div style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgqlBPlwDoD8Fa-Kmh1PfWb2St5CytGcSHNNNuPjvmACdbXZA7xdWV1cQm_ucjvazfm091eVtZcyFteSrXMLrYWDEAjB7tcDY4xoxu3CMSAK0e4J2d6FG1uIBj_I2udbWNwFHHAoeLwkyco4rdCey-0adK5rZBLw1tjAtFzkhheifFsjXRBMxGF6to10w/s1672/image5.png">;<img border="0" data-original-height="713" data-original-width="1672" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgqlBPlwDoD8Fa-Kmh1PfWb2St5CytGcSHNNNuPjvmACdbXZA7xdWV1cQm_ucjvazfm091eVtZcyFteSrXMLrYWDEAjB7tcDY4xoxu3CMSAK0e4J2d6FG1uIBj_I2udbWNwFHHAoeLwkyco4rdCey-0adK5rZBLw1tjAtFzkhheifFsjXRBMxGF6to10w/s16000/image5.png" />;</a>;</div>; </li>; </ul>; <br />; <h2>;Technologies for inclusive and fair ML applications</h2>; <p>; With our continued investment in AI technologies, we are emphasizing responsible AI development with the goal of making our models and tools useful and impactful while also ensuring fairness, safety and alignment with our <a href="https://ai.google/principles/">;AI Principles</a>;. Some of these efforts were highlighted at I/O, including: </p>; <ul>; <li>;The release of the <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/05/consensus-and-subjectivity-of-skin-tone_15.html">;Monk Skin Tone Examples (MST-E) Dataset</a>; to help practitioners gain a deeper understanding of the MST scale and train human annotators for more consistent, inclusive, and meaningful skin tone annotations. You can read more about this and other developments on our <a href="https://skintone.google/">;website</a>;. This is an advancement on the open source release of the <a href="https://blog.google/products/search/monk-skin-tone-scale/">;Monk Skin Tone (MST) Scale</a>; we launched last year to enable developers to build products that are more inclusive and that better represent their diverse users. </li>;<li>;A <a href="https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/asl-fingerspelling/overview/description">;new Kaggle competition</a>; (open until August 10th) in which the ML community is tasked with creating a model that can quickly and accurately identify American Sign Language (ASL) fingerspelling — where each letter of a word is spelled out in ASL rapidly using a single hand, rather than using the specific signs for entire words — and translate it into written text. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q3xKB3dfvtA">;fingerspelling Kaggle competition</a>;, which features a song from <a href="https://www.deafandloud.com/">;Sean Forbes</a>;, a deaf musician and rapper. We also <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WC9x3jp_nV8">;showcased at I/O</a>; the winning algorithm from the prior year's competition powers <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=edu.gatech.popsignai&hl=en_US&gl=US">;PopSign</a>;, an ASL learning app for parents of deaf or hard of hearing children created by Georgia Tech and Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT). </li>; </ul>; <br />; <h2>;Building the future of AI together</h2>; <p>; It's inspiring to be part of a community of so many talented individuals who are leading the way in developing state-of-the-art technologies, responsible AI approaches and exciting user experiences. We are in the midst of a period of incredible and transformative change for AI. Stay tuned for more updates about the ways in which the Google Research community is boldly exploring the frontiers of these technologies and using them responsibly to benefit people's lives around the world. We hope you're as excited as we are about the future of AI technologies and we invite you to engage with our teams through the references, sites and tools that we've highlighted here. scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="User Experience">;</category>;<title type="text">;Resolving code review comments with ML</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Alexander Frömmgen, Staff Software Engineer, and Lera Kharatyan, Senior Software Engineer, Core Systems & Experiences</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjoK3FH1StJnuqrj0gTExqLUxNkVfwRVmiG9tbCNUDV2I5295yqrPlw0L4hRHJmsruvZBIa_FqAFvJfwW7VU4XvxDU4ZweaW6ehENeU7-BLJaLVGPPtn-25cme5qTUldd11YigkAj6Ks9Tif6J3MePey_Gn3cAp3nQf9LMmVy4Eg3yF0qyBZPUKfYJYLw/s2000/comments2code.png" style="display: none;" />; <p>; Code-change reviews are a critical part of the software development process at scale, <a href="https://sback.it/publications/icse2018seip.pdf">;taking</a>; a significant amount of the code authors' and the code reviewers' time. As part of this process, the reviewer inspects the proposed code and asks the author for code changes through comments written in natural language. At Google, we see <a href="https://sback.it/publications/icse2018seip.pdf">;millions of reviewer comments</a>; per year, and authors require an average of ~60 minutes <a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub49446/">;active shepherding time</a>; between sending changes for review and finally submitting the change. In our measurements, the required active work time that the code author must do to address reviewer comments grows almost linearly with the number of comments. However, with machine learning (ML), we have an opportunity to automate and streamline the code review process, eg, by proposing code changes based on a comment's text. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; Today, we describe our application of recent advances in large sequence models (using the <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/05/large-sequence-models-for-software.html">;DIDACT methodology</a>;) in a real-world setting to automatically resolve code review comments in the day-to-day development workflow at Google. As of today, code-change authors at Google address a substantial amount of reviewer comments by applying an ML-suggested edit. We expect that to reduce time spent on code reviews by hundreds of thousands of hours annually at Google scale. Unsolicited, very positive feedback highlights that the impact of ML-suggested code edits increases Googlers' productivity and allows them to focus on more creative and complex tasks. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Predicting the code edit</h2>; <p>; We started by training a model that predicts code edits needed to address reviewer comments. The model is pre-trained on various coding tasks and related developer activities (eg, renaming a variable, repairing a broken build, editing a file). It's then fine-tuned for this specific task with reviewed code changes, the reviewer comments, and the edits the author performed to address those comments. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgRR4C9paw916JEuwW9jTXjFBTt9ii4KEnnXBw2HgxY5MR9muFW3IdJLloAlRV-7AP3Nd8Jg1q633KQS6zfXDlPZlIV8c7KIp9iXgsM2GHJV_iv4e5mCrUhRrT2LFNBpuSFGTLzKDk6w56Km_jOOkWMMdEZlMadlwBDYVGnztFOPk1mo828sWEpUF1O-g/s1523/figure1.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="700" data-original-width="1523" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgRR4C9paw916JEuwW9jTXjFBTt9ii4KEnnXBw2HgxY5MR9muFW3IdJLloAlRV-7AP3Nd8Jg1q633KQS6zfXDlPZlIV8c7KIp9iXgsM2GHJV_iv4e5mCrUhRrT2LFNBpuSFGTLzKDk6w56Km_jOOkWMMdEZlMadlwBDYVGnztFOPk1mo828sWEpUF1O-g/s16000/figure1.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;An example of an ML-suggested edit of refactorings that are spread within the code.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; Google uses a <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/2854146">;monorepo</a>;, a single repository for all of its software artifacts, which allows our training dataset to include all unrestricted code used to build Google's most recent software, as well as previous versions. </p>; <p>; To improve the model quality, we iterated on the training dataset. For example, we compared the model performance for datasets with a single reviewer comment per file to datasets with multiple comments per file, and experimented with classifiers to clean up the training data based on a small, curated dataset to choose the model with the best offline precision and recall metrics. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Serving infrastructure and user experience</h2>; <p>; We designed and implemented the feature on top of the trained model, focusing on the overall user experience and developer efficiency. As part of this, we explored different user experience (UX) alternatives through a series of user studies. We then refined the feature based on insights from an internal beta (ie, a test of the feature in development) including user feedback (eg, a “Was this helpful?” button next to the suggested edit). </p>; <p>; The final model was calibrated for a target <a href="https://developers.google.com/machine-learning/crash-course/classification/precision-and-recall">;precision</a>; of 50%. That is, we tuned the model and the suggestions filtering, so that 50% of suggested edits on our evaluation dataset are correct. In general, increasing the target precision reduces the number of shown suggested edits, and decreasing the target precision leads to more incorrect suggested edits. Incorrect suggested edits take the developers time and reduce the developers' trust in the feature. We found that a target precision of 50% provides a good balance. </p>; <p>; At a high level, for every new reviewer comment, we generate the model input in the same format that is used for training, query the model, and generate the suggested code edit. If the model is confident in the prediction and a few additional heuristics are satisfied, we send the suggested edit to downstream systems. The downstream systems, ie, the code review frontend and the integrated development environment (IDE), expose the suggested edits to the user and log user interactions, such as preview and apply events. A dedicated pipeline collects these logs and generates aggregate insights, eg, the overall acceptance rates as reported in this blog post. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi5csoDiwO-5vBxy3C4hFSW1urE791VDmpjuM2XyuVQvgMzjwrfqdwIKyJaOffDGEI4X3Y1cjTwP0kiRudNVHB6IKbkzo7znabCW16vsmhyOYyeXFOC24RYXIr406expAnjSRiid883LWa1hRiEXjMa2j5SqvTWFUeucRZ4Bjw9moOo7D_zg1pmGE02-g/s1250/figure%202c.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="465" data-original-width="1250" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi5csoDiwO-5vBxy3C4hFSW1urE791VDmpjuM2XyuVQvgMzjwrfqdwIKyJaOffDGEI4X3Y1cjTwP0kiRudNVHB6IKbkzo7znabCW16vsmhyOYyeXFOC24RYXIr406expAnjSRiid883LWa1hRiEXjMa2j5SqvTWFUeucRZ4Bjw9moOo7D_zg1pmGE02-g/s16000/figure%202c.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Architecture of the ML-suggested edits infrastructure. We process code and infrastructure from multiple services, get the model predictions and surface the predictions in the code review tool and IDE.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; The developer interacts with the ML-suggested edits in the code review tool and the IDE. Based on insights from the user studies, the integration into the code review tool is most suitable for a streamlined review experience. The IDE integration provides additional functionality and supports 3-way merging of the ML-suggested edits (left in the figure below) in case of conflicting local changes on top of the reviewed code state (right) into the merge result (center). </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgceQpRBQ0ooZGNUvGgc1j1qnF8YwJaVGmhUF2KUD8F_KlLJVgzoo-VGcJsIRykGR-flujvuXB83a61cVz88tZHKsJPb8h9tLmoI4LDizmHvaSzRhwcQpxmQZtLI12ckyWJmxl9yhqiFYmHF7oKoBEYSJhqiyhVRtYp-nFBB5RH2VLH3Jtauls4ti1Tmw/s958/figure%203%20(25%25).gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="436" data-original-width="958" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgceQpRBQ0ooZGNUvGgc1j1qnF8YwJaVGmhUF2KUD8F_KlLJVgzoo-VGcJsIRykGR-flujvuXB83a61cVz88tZHKsJPb8h9tLmoI4LDizmHvaSzRhwcQpxmQZtLI12ckyWJmxl9yhqiFYmHF7oKoBEYSJhqiyhVRtYp-nFBB5RH2VLH3Jtauls4ti1Tmw/s16000/figure%203%20(25%25).gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;3-way-merge UX in IDE.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Results</h2>; <p>; Offline evaluations indicate that the model addresses 52% of comments with a target precision of 50%. The online metrics of the beta and the full internal launch confirm these offline metrics, ie, we see model suggestions above our target model confidence for around 50% of all relevant reviewer comments. 40% to 50% of all previewed suggested edits are applied by code authors. </p>; <p>; We used the “not helpful” feedback during the beta to identify recurring failure patterns of the model. We implemented serving-time heuristics to filter these and, thus, reduce the number of shown incorrect predictions. With these changes, we traded quantity for quality and observed an increased real-world acceptance rate. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhyN4DWxW8l5pkxQs0zvbrINGkJSUWnLizahvVbmanqdh0KlnxH4mTHVtKDjNn29fq8oJ35BQNYeeF8p_YURKz2qwS7LwAVoBZflochjmcTVJlag1UrSsaY-DLTDB9H0tJTi1emA6nWstqomACKOeVS4DSANGDl-UWpgXfu-PgliUIMFtUOgi7OyUNg2A/s1753/figure%204%20(50%25).gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="802" data-original-width="1753" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhyN4DWxW8l5pkxQs0zvbrINGkJSUWnLizahvVbmanqdh0KlnxH4mTHVtKDjNn29fq8oJ35BQNYeeF8p_YURKz2qwS7LwAVoBZflochjmcTVJlag1UrSsaY-DLTDB9H0tJTi1emA6nWstqomACKOeVS4DSANGDl-UWpgXfu-PgliUIMFtUOgi7OyUNg2A/s16000/figure%204%20(50%25).gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Code review tool UX. The suggestion is shown as part of the comment and can be previewed, applied and rated as helpful or not helpful.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; Our beta launch showed a <em>;discoverability challenge</em>;: code authors only previewed ~20% of all generated suggested edits. We modified the UX and introduced a prominent “Show ML-edit” button (see the figure above) next to the reviewer comment, leading to an overall preview rate of ~40% at launch. We additionally found that suggested edits in the code review tool are often not applicable due to conflicting changes that the author did during the review process. We addressed this with a button in the code review tool that opens the IDE in a merge view for the suggested edit. We now observe that more than 70% of these are applied in the code review tool and fewer than 30% are applied in the IDE. All these changes allowed us to increase the overall fraction of reviewer comments that are addressed with an ML-suggested edit by a factor of 2 from beta to the full internal launch. At Google scale, these results help automate the resolution of hundreds of thousands of comments each year. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgbb5VXmcCaqT7-jtdVBB57Jzb41KhulYqquTk1OAG35-hM-ztMZvQAzh69E-IA-fJMJCkPJ9v7altTmAU9IzkfJrhxqtZdYT7sF-swZ9ThsiOpK5sD2B1bMfxaQlwFKy7dEqEEgDxnF2FOnnMteUgilDPQcvxciDGpaqh4bRfkds5XIQq9-qaZEZkZyw/s1920/figure%207.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="887" data-original-width="1920" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgbb5VXmcCaqT7-jtdVBB57Jzb41KhulYqquTk1OAG35-hM-ztMZvQAzh69E-IA-fJMJCkPJ9v7altTmAU9IzkfJrhxqtZdYT7sF-swZ9ThsiOpK5sD2B1bMfxaQlwFKy7dEqEEgDxnF2FOnnMteUgilDPQcvxciDGpaqh4bRfkds5XIQq9-qaZEZkZyw/s16000/figure%207.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Suggestions filtering funnel.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; We see ML-suggested edits addressing a wide range of reviewer comments in production. This includes simple localized refactorings and refactorings that are spread within the code, as shown in the examples throughout the blog post above. The feature addresses longer and less formally-worded comments that require code generation, refactorings and imports. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi8d6n1irF1I8_8vkOGByJYA_S5K1kxMguPNr9Z212V0yJvTX46rfj7HZT0ggOfcpJPHobT7UQttP_86gxRsPCbBbiuwMKfrzktVCccBTQXWe8l5a_ezmZJMQQ0yl8tXPThkxQR_yV2JejcpFXwhZ0U_ssbKyVcfaLKk_KErzWJ1Dszu0gasvsuTS0gVQ/s1479/figure%205c.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="651" data-original-width="1479" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi8d6n1irF1I8_8vkOGByJYA_S5K1kxMguPNr9Z212V0yJvTX46rfj7HZT0ggOfcpJPHobT7UQttP_86gxRsPCbBbiuwMKfrzktVCccBTQXWe8l5a_ezmZJMQQ0yl8tXPThkxQR_yV2JejcpFXwhZ0U_ssbKyVcfaLKk_KErzWJ1Dszu0gasvsuTS0gVQ/s16000/figure%205c.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Example of a suggestion for a longer and less formally worded comment that requires code generation, refactorings and imports.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; The model can also respond to complex comments and produce extensive code edits (shown below). The generated test case follows the existing unit test pattern, while changing the details as described in the comment. Additionally, the edit suggests a comprehensive name for the test reflecting the test semantics. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgPJQaVUZNW7KVuLtF1n_Gxhe1wg8QcElAABAp4AQH-B6mnt5N2-xZqEnK5VnEoy5eqXrdwR__xICAHDUYxb3wC25M_XA7gdJCN0l4mavhLNSxzC4lUqXL-7x3FD4M9SNEvgdmLzN5jcX727V4QEgAxn36BN_R7l4HQmjzwG6e9v6Vq1HzFKy1s8H01SA/s1497/figure%206c.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="648" data-original-width="1497" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgPJQaVUZNW7KVuLtF1n_Gxhe1wg8QcElAABAp4AQH-B6mnt5N2-xZqEnK5VnEoy5eqXrdwR__xICAHDUYxb3wC25M_XA7gdJCN0l4mavhLNSxzC4lUqXL-7x3FD4M9SNEvgdmLzN5jcX727V4QEgAxn36BN_R7l4HQmjzwG6e9v6Vq1HzFKy1s8H01SA/s16000/figure%206c.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Example of the model's ability to respond to complex comments and produce extensive code edits.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Conclusion and future work</h2>; <p>; In this post, we introduced an ML-assistance feature to reduce the time spent on code review related changes. At the moment, a substantial amount of all actionable code review comments on supported languages are addressed with applied ML-suggested edits at Google. A 12-week A/B experiment across all Google developers will further measure the impact of the feature on the overall developer productivity. </p>; <p>; We are working on improvements throughout the whole stack. This includes increasing the quality and recall of the model and building a more streamlined experience for the developer with improved discoverability throughout the review process. As part of this, we are investigating the option of showing suggested edits to the reviewer while they draft comments and expanding the feature into the IDE to enable code-change authors to get suggested code edits for natural-language commands. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>; <em>;This is the work of many people in Google Core Systems & Experiences team, Google Research, and DeepMind. scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Deep Learning">;</category>;<category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Security and Privacy">;</category>;<title type="text">;Making ML models differentially private: Best practices and open challenges</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Natalia Ponomareva and Alex Kurakin, Staff Software Engineers, Google Research</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhqMCb-nNfoCncADD29b0YyxB4wN8bOhRph7pJBGzKyYc1bvdZ10VC3RkyUCJBopmvukjXJnZiJyiZ5ZIPyIW66ZfrYmBoJFrxx35T8OrL_HmNr4YIKzBS5y6Ej24f1Mjsu-IqH5ECyzPBRKDRtoGgQhoKoOpILElqHDIGsn9SiI-7x58qc_nbtQ1JZ1A/s320/DPfy%20hero.gif" style="display: none;" />; <p>; Large machine learning (ML) models are ubiquitous in modern applications: from <a href="https://workspace.google.com/blog/identity-and-security/an-overview-of-gmails-spam-filters">;spam filters</a>; to <a href="https://developers.google.com/machine-learning/recommendation/overview/types">;recommender systems</a>; and <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/07/look-and-talk-natural-conversations.html">;virtual assistants</a>;. These models achieve remarkable performance partially due to the abundance of available training data. However, these data can sometimes contain private information, including personal identifiable information, copyright material, etc. Therefore, protecting the privacy of the training data is critical to practical, applied ML. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_privacy">;Differential Privacy</a>; (DP) is one of the most widely accepted technologies that allows reasoning about data anonymization in a formal way. In the context of an ML model, DP can guarantee that each individual user's contribution will not result in a significantly different model. A model's privacy guarantees are characterized by a tuple (<em>;ε</em>;, <em>;δ</em>;), where smaller values of both represent stronger DP guarantees and better privacy. </p>; <p>; While there are successful <a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub52351/">;examples</a>; of <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/02/federated-learning-with-formal.html">;protecting training data</a>; using DP, obtaining good utility with differentially private ML (DP-ML) techniques can be challenging. First, there are inherent privacy/computation tradeoffs that may limit a model's utility. Further, DP-ML models often require architectural and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperparameter_optimization">;hyperparameter</a>; tuning, and guidelines on how to do this effectively are limited or difficult to find. Finally, non-rigorous privacy reporting makes it challenging to compare and choose the best DP methods. </p>; <p>; In “<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00654">;How to DP-fy ML: A Practical Guide to Machine Learning with Differential Privacy</a>;”, to appear in the <em>;<a href="https://www.jair.org/index.php/jair">;Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research</a>;</em>;, we discuss the current state of DP-ML research. We provide an overview of common techniques for obtaining DP-ML models and discuss research, engineering challenges, mitigation techniques and current open questions. We will present tutorials based on this work at <a href="https://icml.cc/Conferences/2023">;ICML 2023</a>; and <a href="https://kdd.org/kdd2023/">;KDD 2023</a>;. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;DP-ML methods</h2>; <p>; DP can be introduced during the ML model development process in three places: (1) at the input data level, (2) during training, or (3) at inference. Each option provides privacy protections at different stages of the ML development process, with the weakest being when DP is introduced at the prediction level and the strongest being when introduced at the input level. Making the input data differentially private means that any model that is trained on this data will also have DP guarantees. When introducing DP during the training, only that particular model has DP guarantees. DP at the prediction level means that only the model's predictions are protected, but the model itself is not differentially private. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhm6JbnVKbvGHMOesXYhP2AWZqVWeYqZGL4Hp4xruQmLzGZNv_Pb0tweOOmSznicm06Fb0Dk6G4HpE5hp2hOeAY0BWCO04rL1w_tdE5JC3jBbmPzMRpGQgf9z1jYYszQyltM3rvXaHLG7__JnePH9MEVG_YTSFYEQdYHQUTJXxVjzyCjREw0Bj4I4It3w/s1821/image2.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="446" data-original-width="1821" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhm6JbnVKbvGHMOesXYhP2AWZqVWeYqZGL4Hp4xruQmLzGZNv_Pb0tweOOmSznicm06Fb0Dk6G4HpE5hp2hOeAY0BWCO04rL1w_tdE5JC3jBbmPzMRpGQgf9z1jYYszQyltM3rvXaHLG7__JnePH9MEVG_YTSFYEQdYHQUTJXxVjzyCjREw0Bj4I4It3w/s16000/image2.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;The task of introducing DP gets progressively easier from the left to right.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; DP is commonly introduced during training (DP-training). <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.00654.pdf">;Gradient noise injection</a>; methods, like <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1607.00133">;DP-SGD</a>; or <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.00039">;DP-FTRL</a>;, and their extensions are currently the most practical methods for achieving DP guarantees in complex models like large deep neural networks. </p>; <p>; DP-SGD builds off of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent">;stochastic gradient descent</a>; (SGD) optimizer with two modifications: (1) per-example gradients are clipped to a certain norm to limit sensitivity (the influence of an individual example on the overall model), which is a slow and computationally intensive process, and (2) a noisy gradient update is formed by taking aggregated gradients and adding noise that is proportional to the sensitivity and the strength of privacy guarantees. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgQqxkabmVXlVWrPH4rEop_ZFxMo_DtkzllZq3JIpstNNxAxutrZe-kS24Vqi1b2r4BvF1zEP3hpZGEvoExnJHKqgnREGcgTJWSjmfglItZAa_ZHLrsTTRvLBxY4z6nmeJoT1ptEnM9dkM82Iq8_FCA2lmUZclzmLsqfDZ2czAcHQW_8PnabZvy1ZYBXw/s1439/DP-ML.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="494" data-original-width="1439" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgQqxkabmVXlVWrPH4rEop_ZFxMo_DtkzllZq3JIpstNNxAxutrZe-kS24Vqi1b2r4BvF1zEP3hpZGEvoExnJHKqgnREGcgTJWSjmfglItZAa_ZHLrsTTRvLBxY4z6nmeJoT1ptEnM9dkM82Iq8_FCA2lmUZclzmLsqfDZ2czAcHQW_8PnabZvy1ZYBXw/s16000/DP-ML.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;DP-SGD is a modification of SGD that involves a) clipping per-example gradients to limit the sensitivity and b) adding the noise, calibrated to the sensitivity and privacy guarantees, to the aggregated gradients, before the gradient update step. </td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Existing DP-training challenges</h2>; <p>; Gradient noise injection methods usually exhibit: (1) loss of utility, (2) slower training, and (3) an increased <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_footprint">;memory footprint</a>;. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Loss of utility</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;The best method for reducing utility drop is to use more computation. Using larger batch sizes and/or more iterations is one of the most prominent and practical ways of improving a model's performance. Hyperparameter tuning is also extremely important but often overlooked. The utility of DP-trained models is sensitive to the total amount of noise added, which depends on hyperparameters, like the clipping norm and batch size. Additionally, other hyperparameters like the learning rate should be re-tuned to account for noisy gradient updates. </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Another option is to obtain more data or use public data of similar distribution. This can be done by leveraging publicly available checkpoints, like <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1512.03385">;ResNet</a>; or <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/1910.10683.pdf">;T5</a>;, and fine-tuning them using private data. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Slower training</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Most gradient noise injection methods limit sensitivity via clipping per-example gradients, considerably slowing down <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation">;backpropagation</a>;. This can be addressed by choosing an efficient DP framework that efficiently implements per-example clipping. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Increased memory footprint</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;DP-training requires significant memory for computing and storing per-example gradients. Additionally, it requires significantly larger batches to obtain better utility. Increasing the computation resources (eg, the number and size of accelerators) is the simplest solution for extra memory requirements. Alternatively, <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2109.12298">;several</a>; <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.12328">;works</a>; advocate for gradient accumulation where smaller batches are combined to simulate a larger batch before the gradient update is applied. Further, some algorithms (eg, <a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/2110.05679.pdf">;ghost clipping</a>;, which is based on <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1510.01799">;this paper</a>;) avoid per-example gradient clipping altogether. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Best practices</h2>; <p>; The following best practices can attain rigorous DP guarantees with the best model utility possible. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Choosing the right privacy unit:</strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;First, we should be clear about a model's privacy guarantees. This is encoded by selecting the “privacy unit,” which represents the neighboring dataset concept (ie, datasets where only one row is different). Example-level protection is a common choice in the research literature, but may not be ideal, however, for user-generated data if individual users contributed multiple records to the training dataset. For such a case, user-level protection might be more appropriate. For text and sequence data, the choice of the unit is harder since in most applications individual training examples are not aligned to the semantic meaning embedded in the text. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Choosing privacy guarantees:</strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;We outline three broad tiers of privacy guarantees and encourage practitioners to choose the lowest possible tier below: </p>; <ul style="margin-left: 4em;">; <li>;<em>;Tier 1 — Strong privacy guarantees:</em>; Choosing <em>;ε</em>; ≤ 1 provides a strong privacy guarantee, but frequently results in a significant utility drop for large models and thus may only be feasible for smaller models. </li>;<li>;<em>;Tier 2 — Reasonable privacy guarantees:</em>; We advocate for the currently undocumented, but still widely used, goal for DP-ML models to achieve an <em>;ε</em>; ≤ 10. </li>;<li>;<em>;Tier 3 — Weak privacy guarantees:</em>; Any finite <em>;ε</em>; is an improvement over a model with no formal privacy guarantee. However, for <em>;ε</em>; > 10, the DP guarantee alone cannot be taken as sufficient evidence of data anonymization, and additional measures (eg, empirical privacy auditing) may be necessary to ensure the model protects user data. </li>; </ul>; <p>; <strong>;Hyperparameter tuning</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Choosing hyperparameters requires optimizing over three inter-dependent objectives: 1) model utility, 2) privacy cost <em>;ε</em>;, and 3) computation cost. Common strategies take two of the three as constraints, and focus on optimizing the third. We provide methods that will maximize the utility with a limited number of trials, eg, tuning with privacy and computation constraints. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Reporting privacy guarantees: </strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;A lot of works on DP for ML report only <em>;ε</em>; and possibly <em>;δ </em>;values for their training procedure. However, we believe that practitioners should provide a comprehensive overview of model guarantees that includes: </p>; <ol style="margin-left: 4em;">; <li>;<em>;DP setting:</em>; Are the results assuming central DP with a trusted service provider, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_differential_privacy">;local DP</a>;, or some other setting? </li>;<li>;<em>;Instantiating the DP definition:</em>; <ol type="a">; <li>;<em>;Data accesses covered:</em>; Whether the DP guarantee applies (only) to a single training run or also covers hyperparameter tuning etc. </li>;<li>;<em>;Final mechanism's output</em>;: What is covered by the privacy guarantees and can be released publicly (eg, model checkpoints, the full sequence of privatized gradients, etc.) </li>;<li>;<em>;Unit of privacy</em>;: The selected “privacy unit” (example-level, user-level, etc.) </li>;<li>;<em>;Adjacency definition</em>; for DP “neighboring” datasets: A description of how neighboring datasets differ (eg, add-or-remove, replace-one, zero-out-one). </li>; </ol>; </li>;<li>;<em>;Privacy accounting details:</em>; Providing accounting details, eg, composition and amplification, are important for proper comparison between methods and should include: <ol type="a">; <li>;Type of accounting used, eg, <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1702.07476">;Rényi DP</a>;-based accounting, PLD accounting, etc. </li>;<li>;Accounting assumptions and whether they hold (eg, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poisson_regression#Maximum_likelihood-based_parameter_estimation">;Poisson</a>; sampling was assumed for privacy amplification but data shuffling was used in training). </li>;<li>;Formal DP statement for the model and tuning process (eg, the specific <em>;ε</em>;, <em>;δ</em>;-DP or <em>;<a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/1605.02065.pdf">;ρ-zCDP</a>;</em>; values). </li>; </ol>; </li>;<li>;<em>;Transparency and verifiability:</em>; When possible, complete open-source code using standard DP libraries for the key mechanism implementation and accounting components. </li>; </ol>; <p>; <strong>;Paying attention to all the components used:</strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Usually, DP-training is a straightforward application of DP-SGD or other algorithms. However, some components or losses that are often used in ML models (eg, <a href="https://www.baeldung.com/cs/contrastive-learning#:~:text=Contrastive%20Loss,and%20dissimilar%20samples%20far%20apart.">;contrastive losses</a>;, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network">;graph neural network</a>; layers) should be examined to ensure privacy guarantees are not violated. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Open questions</h2>; <p>; While DP-ML is an active research area, we highlight the broad areas where there is room for improvement. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Developing better accounting methods</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Our current understanding of DP-training <em>;ε</em>;, <em>;δ<strong>; </strong>;</em>;guarantees<strong>; </strong>;relies on a number of techniques, like Rényi DP composition and privacy amplification. We believe that better accounting methods for existing algorithms will demonstrate that DP guarantees for ML models are actually better than expected. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Developing better algorithms:</strong>; </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;The computational burden of using gradient noise injection for DP-training comes from the need to use larger batches and limit per-example sensitivity. Developing methods that can use smaller batches or identifying other ways (apart from per-example clipping) to limit the sensitivity would be a breakthrough for DP-ML. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Better optimization techniques</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;Directly applying the same DP-SGD recipe is believed to be suboptimal for adaptive optimizers because the noise added to privatize the gradient may accumulate in learning rate computation. Designing theoretically grounded DP adaptive optimizers remains an active research topic. Another potential direction is to better understand the surface of DP loss, since for standard (non-DP) ML models flatter regions have been shown to <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.01412">;generalize</a>; <a href="https://openreview.net/pdf?id=H1oyRlYgg">;better</a>;. </p>; <p>; <strong>;Identifying architectures that are more robust to noise</strong>;: </p>; <p style="margin-left: 3em;">;There's an opportunity to better understand whether we need to adjust the architecture of an existing model when introducing DP. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Conclusion</h2>; <p>; Our <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00654">;survey paper</a>; summarizes the current research related to making ML models DP, and provides practical tips on how to achieve the best privacy-utility trade offs. Our hope is that this work will serve as a reference point for the practitioners who want to effectively apply DP to complex ML models. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>; <em>;We thank Hussein Hazimeh, Zheng Xu , Carson Denison , H. Brendan McMahan, Sergei Vassilvitskii, Steve Chien and Abhradeep Thakurta, Badih Ghazi, Chiyuan Zhang for the help preparing this blog post, paper and tutorials content. Thanks to John Guilyard for creating the graphics in this post, and Ravi Kumar for comments.</em>; </p>;</content>;<link href="http://ai.googleblog.com/feeds/3261601760457492933/comments/default" scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Video Analysis">;</category>;<title type="text">;Sparse video tubes for joint video and image vision transformers</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by AJ Piergiovanni and Anelia Angelova, Research Scientists, Google</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEg5vGQDyw66Z4hevP1JdKXnn8OCKudaDk2bacIPBkxtSYH1BgyNqXhK2QXOr-ANdX6MfoZp-jzVsETmH6kgy_Tvnii7ylDJEA-u5pJXareZRDyIBsRqguw2-AcDejtp3HXImtSLXKs_wUfMf8plDnpWzk1KGCgmm0U_j31qGh3rU4Cyv58HTpiocpyZiA/s320/TubeViT%20hero.jpg" style="display: none;" />; <p>; Video understanding is a challenging problem that requires reasoning about both spatial information (eg, for objects in a scene, including their locations and relations) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_information_retrieval#:~:text=Temporal%20information%20retrieval%20(T%2DIR,of%20the%20user%20information%20needs.">;temporal information</a>; for activities or events shown in a video. There are many video understanding applications and tasks, such as <a href="https://cloud.google.com/video-intelligence">;understanding the semantic content of web videos</a>; and <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/02/robot-see-robot-do.html">;robot perception</a>;. However, current works, such as <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.15691">;ViViT</a>; and <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2102.05095">;TimeSFormer</a>;, densely process the video and require significant compute, especially as model size plus video length and resolution increase. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; In “<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03229">;Rethinking Video ViTs: Sparse Video Tubes for Joint Image and Video Learning</a>;”, to be presented at <a href="https://cvpr2023.thecvf.com/Conferences/2023">;CVPR 2023</a>;, we introduce a simple technique that turns a <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.11929">;Vision Transformer</a>; (ViT) model image encoder into an efficient video backbone using sparse video tubes (learnable visual representations of samples from the video) to reduce the model's compute needs. This approach can seamlessly process both images and videos, which allows it to leverage both image and video data sources during training. This training further enables our sparse tubes ViT model to coalesce image and video backbones together to serve a dual role as either an image or video backbone (or both), depending on the input. We demonstrate that this model is scalable, can be adapted to large pre-trained ViTs without requiring full fine-tuning, and achieves state-of-the-art results across many video classification benchmarks. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgMB86kM4i14vA4RTy6ZcFbxosHQJ-jtMmsFrIsg32wAwrwkeeewMzC1tpTP-i5ukgLVq93yLq4ELx6o7xhi3SIiM0ir4fGyzbZH5PJ823gaC3EHb3AdRgtM3SGkTrAnrDPnDc5qow_RVopG3H4xTjV7UmdRwqipD5tjRcPW3s9fwJVGJW7cb3Ybb-44A/s860/image5.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="219" data-original-width="860" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgMB86kM4i14vA4RTy6ZcFbxosHQJ-jtMmsFrIsg32wAwrwkeeewMzC1tpTP-i5ukgLVq93yLq4ELx6o7xhi3SIiM0ir4fGyzbZH5PJ823gaC3EHb3AdRgtM3SGkTrAnrDPnDc5qow_RVopG3H4xTjV7UmdRwqipD5tjRcPW3s9fwJVGJW7cb3Ybb-44A/s16000/image5.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Using sparse video tubes to sample a video, combined with a standard ViT encoder, leads to an efficient visual representation that can be seamlessly shared with image inputs.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>;<br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Building a joint image-video backbone</h2>; <p>; Our sparse tube ViT uses a standard ViT backbone, consisting of a stack of <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2017/08/transformer-novel-neural-network.html">;Transformer</a>; layers, that processes video information. Previous methods, such as ViViT, densely tokenize the video and then apply <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.15691">;factorized attention</a>;, ie, the attention weights for each token are computed separately for the temporal and spatial dimensions. In the standard ViT architecture, self-attention is computed over the whole token sequence. When using videos as input, token sequences become quite long, which can make this computation slow. Instead, in the method we propose, the video is sparsely sampled using <em>;video tubes</em>;, which are 3D learnable visual representations of various shapes and sizes (described in more detail below) from the video. These tubes are used to sparsely sample the video using a <a href="https://www.coursera.org/lecture/convolutional-neural-networks/strided-convolutions-wfUhx">;large temporal stride</a>;, ie, when a tube kernel is only applied to a few locations in the video, rather than every pixel. </p>; <p>; By sparsely sampling the video tubes, we can use the same global self-attention module, rather than factorized attention like ViViT. We experimentally show that the addition of factorized attention layers can harm the performance due to the uninitialized weights. This single stack of transformer layers in the ViT backbone also enables better sharing of the weights and improves performance. Sparse video tube sampling is done by using a large spatial and temporal stride that selects tokens on a fixed grid. The large stride reduces the number of tokens in the full network, while still capturing both spatial and temporal information and enabling the efficient processing of all tokens. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Sparse video tubes</h2>; <p>; Video tubes are 3D grid-based cuboids that can have different shapes or categories and capture different information with strides and starting locations that can overlap. In the model, we use three distinct tube shapes that capture: (1) only spatial information (resulting in a set of 2D image patches), (2) long temporal information (over a small spatial area), and (3) both spatial and temporal information equally. Tubes that capture only spatial information can be applied to both image and video inputs. Tubes that capture long temporal information or both temporal and spatial information equally are only applied to video inputs. Depending on the input video size, the three tube shapes are applied to the model multiple times to generate tokens. </p>; <p>; A fixed position embedding, which captures the global location of each tube (including any strides, offsets, etc.) relative to all the other tubes, is applied to the video tubes. Different from the previous learned position embeddings, this fixed one better enables sparse, overlapping sampling. Capturing the global location of the tube helps the model know where each came from, which is especially helpful when tubes overlap or are sampled from distant video locations. Next, the tube features are concatenated together to form a set of <em>;N</em>; tokens. These tokens are processed by a standard ViT encoder. Finally, we apply an attention pooling to compress all the tokens into a single representation and input to a fully connected (FC) layer to make the classification (eg, playing soccer, swimming, etc.). </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgEaxZgk0mko5p-W6Tk3puhe9jq7seDBa8KAyxBYZZFaipGGx0kNmCq7mvrW-A--zFu-lz49-09utLfkP1ef9IC3qh_wReFrSfYqhJgfbVwBefVlR_GVrvr-Xvsn4y_ib53SbigVnTHa2m8gw-4i0Ez9g1jqn03Gpv0JJPJTh4G3iSO3O-mX9JY8Z6HfQ/s474/image2.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="474" data-original-width="346" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgEaxZgk0mko5p-W6Tk3puhe9jq7seDBa8KAyxBYZZFaipGGx0kNmCq7mvrW-A--zFu-lz49-09utLfkP1ef9IC3qh_wReFrSfYqhJgfbVwBefVlR_GVrvr-Xvsn4y_ib53SbigVnTHa2m8gw-4i0Ez9g1jqn03Gpv0JJPJTh4G3iSO3O-mX9JY8Z6HfQ/s16000/image2.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Our video ViT model works by sampling sparse video tubes from the video (shown at the bottom) to enable either or both image or video inputs to be seamlessly processed. These tubes have different shapes and capture different video features. Tube 1 (<strong>;yellow</strong>;) only captures spatial information, resulting in a set of 2D patches that can be applied to image inputs. Tube 2 (<strong>;red</strong>;) captures temporal information and some spatial information and tube 3 (<strong>;green</strong>;) equally captures both temporal and spatial information (ie, the spatial size of the tube <em>;x</em>; and <em>;y</em>; are the same as the number of frames <em>;t</em>;). Tubes 2 and 3 can only be applied to video inputs. The position embedding is added to all the tube features.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Scaling video ViTs</h2>; <p>; The process of building video backbones is computationally intensive, but our sparse tube ViT model enables computationally efficient scaling of video models, leveraging previously trained image backbones. Since image backbones can be adapted to a video backbone, large image backbones can be turned into large video backbones. More specifically, one can transfer the learned video feature representations from a small tube ViT to a large pre-trained image ViT and train the resulting model with video data for only a few steps, as opposed to a full training from scratch. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjXSbl0uJ2k_vpBU1Ll0PF93KVqUFB_NAk_Wy4pCyUCF8-LYUDDB209aneR4c5Nx_1lCMk74sBNZthIDM2G27B35UE0sV0pYkcsIW0XBtSdMagBkcdIrbELMxWCLurV2o-DqyeMyuYlKkc__KNQNvCasGCBEelQ5jmb5dMKpG-bhQ4xAPaLGi-8CP6kYw/s899/image6.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="500" data-original-width="899" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjXSbl0uJ2k_vpBU1Ll0PF93KVqUFB_NAk_Wy4pCyUCF8-LYUDDB209aneR4c5Nx_1lCMk74sBNZthIDM2G27B35UE0sV0pYkcsIW0XBtSdMagBkcdIrbELMxWCLurV2o-DqyeMyuYlKkc__KNQNvCasGCBEelQ5jmb5dMKpG-bhQ4xAPaLGi-8CP6kYw/s16000/image6.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Our approach enables scaling a sparse tube ViT in a more efficient way. Specifically, the video features from a small video ViT (<strong>;top network</strong>;) can be transferred to a large, pre-trained image ViT (<strong>;bottom network</strong>;), and further fine-tuned. This requires fewer training steps to achieve strong performance with the large model. This is beneficial as large video models might be prohibitively expensive to train from scratch.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Results</h2>; <p>; We evaluate our sparse tube ViT approach using <a href="https://www.deepmind.com/open-source/kinetics">;Kinetics-400</a>; (shown below), Kinetics-600 and Kinetics-700 datasets and compare its performance to a long list of prior methods. We find that our approach outperforms all prior methods. Importantly, it outperforms all state-of-the-art methods trained jointly on image+video datasets. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgDFFJWQ_xEQcssI_Z0A4AbsuIzVDvttvYLhiVvt0QAivawWM27oUJNOo766KXnbf8vpcQvE2WKWhwvm00nJ10XWwjYxiFKRZEyQaJAgjEOfYBVbXO0Mio7Z1NgEczOR1fF36r-nBonPI7dfWnRQRREcu7a6XJ4lVWcY3T90jgruakIR75OlnmmOGhzBQ/s600/image1.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="371" data-original-width="600" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgDFFJWQ_xEQcssI_Z0A4AbsuIzVDvttvYLhiVvt0QAivawWM27oUJNOo766KXnbf8vpcQvE2WKWhwvm00nJ10XWwjYxiFKRZEyQaJAgjEOfYBVbXO0Mio7Z1NgEczOR1fF36r-nBonPI7dfWnRQRREcu7a6XJ4lVWcY3T90jgruakIR75OlnmmOGhzBQ/s16000/image1.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Performance compared to several prior works on the popular Kinetics-400 video dataset. Our sparse tube ViT outperforms state-of-the-art methods.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; Furthermore, we test our sparse tube ViT model on the <a href="https://developer.qualcomm.com/software/ai-datasets/something-something">;Something-Something V2</a>; dataset, which is commonly used to evaluate more dynamic activities, and also report that it outperforms all prior state-of-the-art approaches. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjEusff29OZ6p1q03d-WXctJ86ceGEZKTz931L81Ah8MbVUqH8hk_jZBQ_Ob0lnR9fxZABknMJilDBXLwc3b9fV0wTunsjBBQbEnNBVFwiD20X25RUB5KJknjQtiwzMl2lTrga8XY-HDhhw6wDfdpNufEF4QIV-9FbTquOLebaO4P7YqSEa7fg0N6EqGw/s600/image4.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="371" data-original-width="600" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjEusff29OZ6p1q03d-WXctJ86ceGEZKTz931L81Ah8MbVUqH8hk_jZBQ_Ob0lnR9fxZABknMJilDBXLwc3b9fV0wTunsjBBQbEnNBVFwiD20X25RUB5KJknjQtiwzMl2lTrga8XY-HDhhw6wDfdpNufEF4QIV-9FbTquOLebaO4P7YqSEa7fg0N6EqGw/s16000/image4.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Performance on the Something-Something V2 video dataset.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Visualizing some learned kernels</h2>; <p>; It is interesting to understand what kind of rudimentary features are being learned by the proposed model. We visualize them below, showing both the 2D patches, which are shared for both images and videos, and video tubes. These visualizations show the 2D or 3D information being captured by the projection layer. For example, in the 2D patches, various common features, like edges and colors, are detected, while the 3D tubes capture basic shapes and how they may change over time. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjThXmwg6c2miOzHrFodzuyhZ2inlHe3SeUfXfV-xpwYNsVj0bQD4QcLrRNM7MRZy4gqJ97PCeABtc-JioR5kkJXkEtd3KiealEKgmvwRu33j6xHVvvd9ylKPMUit6em59orJw4YHlMVMT-gfro4MXp1ESFclsZn3vZVkEqxxkSVsucgQZ-f5NXbImv6w/s549/image3.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="285" data-original-width="549" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjThXmwg6c2miOzHrFodzuyhZ2inlHe3SeUfXfV-xpwYNsVj0bQD4QcLrRNM7MRZy4gqJ97PCeABtc-JioR5kkJXkEtd3KiealEKgmvwRu33j6xHVvvd9ylKPMUit6em59orJw4YHlMVMT-gfro4MXp1ESFclsZn3vZVkEqxxkSVsucgQZ-f5NXbImv6w/s16000/image3.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Visualizations of patches and tubes learned the sparse tube ViT model. Top row are the 2D patches and the remaining two rows are snapshots from the learned video tubes. The tubes show each patch for the 8 or 4 frames to which they are applied.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Conclusions</h2>; <p>; We have presented a new sparse tube ViT, which can turn a ViT encoder into an efficient video model, and can seamlessly work with both image and video inputs. We also showed that large video encoders can be bootstrapped from small video encoders and image-only ViTs. Our approach outperforms prior methods across several popular video understanding benchmarks. We believe that this simple representation can facilitate much more efficient learning with input videos, seamlessly incorporate either image or video inputs and effectively eliminate the bifurcation of image and video models for future multimodal understanding. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>; <em>;This work is conducted by AJ Piergiovanni, Weicheng Kuo and Anelia Angelova, who are now at Google DeepMind. We thank Abhijit Ogale, Luowei Zhou, Claire Cui and our colleagues in Google Research for their helpful discussions, comments, and support.</em>; </p>;<br />;</content>;<link href="http://ai.googleblog.com/feeds/234098392689663352/comments/default" rel="replies" title="Post Comments" type="application/atom+xml"/>;<link href="http://ai.googleblog.com/2023/05/sparse-video-tubes-for-joint-video-and.html#comment-form" rel="replies" title="0 Comments" type="text/html"/>;<link href="http://www.blogger.com/feeds/8474926331452026626/posts/default/234098392689663352" rel="edit" type="application/atom+xml"/>;<link href="http://www.blogger.com/feeds/8474926331452026626/posts/default/234098392689663352" rel="self" type="application/atom+xml"/>;<link href="http://ai.googleblog.com/2023/05/sparse-video-tubes-for-joint-video-and.html" rel="alternate" title="Sparse video tubes for joint video and image vision transformers" type="text/html"/>;<author>;<name>;Google AI</name>;<uri>;http://www.blogger.com/profile/12098626514775266161</uri>;<email>;noreply@blogger.com</email>;<gd:image height="16" rel="http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail" src="https://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif" width="16">;</gd:image>;</author>;<media:thumbnail height="72" url="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEg5vGQDyw66Z4hevP1JdKXnn8OCKudaDk2bacIPBkxtSYH1BgyNqXhK2QXOr-ANdX6MfoZp-jzVsETmH6kgy_Tvnii7ylDJEA-u5pJXareZRDyIBsRqguw2-AcDejtp3HXImtSLXKs_wUfMf8plDnpWzk1KGCgmm0U_j31qGh3rU4Cyv58HTpiocpyZiA/s72-c/TubeViT%20hero.jpg" width="72" xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/">;</media:thumbnail>;<thr:total>;0</thr:total>;</entry>;</feed>;
